hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Umar ibn al-Khattab: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: Verily the owner of the beast has the most right to its saddle.

narrators.name: Umar ibn al-Khattab

chainIssues: Multiple narrators report using 'an (عَنْ) from position 3 onwards, introducing potential ambiguity
Transition from direct transmission terms (حَدَّثَنَا/نا) to indirect terms ('an) between Ibn Ayyash and Abu Sabah
Several narrators are graded as Saduq rather than Thiqah, weakening the chain

potential_issues.issue: Chain contains multiple 'an (عَنْ) connections from Abu Sabah onwards
potential_issues.impact: While not uncommon, the accumulation of indirect transmission terms (عَنْ) from narrators of Saduq grade reduces the chain's overall strength compared to direct transmission terms

potential_issues.issue: Ibn Ayyash is reported to have experienced ikhtilat (confusion) in his later years
potential_issues.impact: The reliability of narrations from Ibn Ayyash depends on whether his narration occurred before or after the onset of confusion. This requires investigation into when his narrations were collected

potential_issues.issue: Narrators Abu Sabah, Abu al-Yamān, al-Walid, and Urah are all graded as Saduq
potential_issues.impact: The predominance of Saduq-graded narrators in the chain, despite their general reliability, means the hadith falls below the 'Sahih' standard which requires all narrators to be Thiqah or equivalent

potential_issues.issue: The chain structure shows weak transmission from the companion Umar to the Prophet ﷺ
potential_issues.impact: This could be interpreted as mursal-like if the direct connection is questioned, though companion reports are generally more accepted

Topics: Rights of the beast of burden owner
Dialogue between Umar and the Prophet ﷺ

potential_issues.issue: Abu Said al-Ju'fi is classified as Da'if (weak)
potential_issues.impact: This is a critical weakness in the chain. Abu Said al-Ju'fi is known for poor memory and weak transmission. His presence in the chain severely compromises the hadith's authenticity

potential_issues.issue: Said (position 5) appears to be unidentified with only 'an transmission
potential_issues.impact: An unidentified narrator with only 'an transmission creates a significant disconnection point in the chain. This contributes to the overall weakness of the hadith

potential_issues.issue: The transition from Ibn Wahb and Amr (both Thiqah) to Said (Majhul al-Hal) and then Shaybah
potential_issues.impact: The abrupt shift from reliable narrators to weak/unknown ones suggests the hadith likely underwent transmission through different, less reliable pathways

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated: Abd al-Rahman ibn Awf approached the Prophet ﷺ and said: O Messenger of Allah, I missed that expedition while I was preparing my provisions. Inform me of an action by which I may reach their rank. The Prophet ﷺ said to him: Alas, alas, you cannot do that. He said: Or fasting or prayer or charity? The Prophet ﷺ asked: Can you stand without sleeping and fast without breaking your fast until they return? He said: No. The Prophet ﷺ said: If you did that, you would not reach their ranks.

narrators.name: Safwan ibn Amr
narrators.full_name: Ziyad ibn Fayrus al-Baraa (known as Abu al-Aaliyah)
narrators.alternative_names: Abu al-Aaliyah al-Riyahi, Ziyad ibn Fayrus

narrators.name: An anonymous man from the people of Damascus
Prophet Muhammad ﷺ

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated: Malik ibn Abdullah saw a companion walking and leading his horse at Dhat al-Jawn. He called to him: O brother, why don't you ride? He replied: I heard the Messenger of Allah ﷺ say: Whoever has dusty feet in the way of Allah, Mighty and Exalted, Paradise will be obligatory for him. So I want that to be obligatory for me from my Lord, and let my beast be returned to me. Let it enrich me from my companion's beast. Malik said: Allah is Greatest! Then he dismounted and the people dismounted with him, all together, and they led their beasts. Ibn Ayyash said: The one who was walking was Iyad ibn Ghunam.

narrators.name: Malik ibn Abdullah
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Abdullah al-Wuhazi (subject of narration)

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib al-Hashimi

chainIssues: Ismail ibn Ayyash is known as mudallis but is La Ba'sa Bihi grade, making his transmission acceptable
Chain contains mix of direct (نا) and indirect (عَنْ) transmission terms

potential_issues.issue: Ismail ibn Ayyash is classified as mudallis
potential_issues.impact: While he is La Ba'sa Bihi grade which is generally acceptable, scholars note his tendency to conceal transmission. However, his use of 'naa' (direct transmission) here makes the narration acceptable

potential_issues.issue: Multiple Saduq-graded narrators in the chain
potential_issues.impact: The chain lacks the highest tier of reliability (Thiqah), which prevents it from reaching Sahih status. Hasan status is appropriate

potential_issues.issue: Narrative construction using 'anna from Zurah
potential_issues.impact: The use of 'anna indicates an indirect narrative form which is less direct than explicit statement, but not significantly problematic given the narrator reliability

Topics: Virtue of dusty feet in the path of Allah
Incident of companion walking to gain reward
Dialogue between Malik ibn Abdullah and a companion

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Al-Hakam ibn Minaa: The Prophet ﷺ said to Umar: Gather for me from the Quraysh who are here. Umar asked: O Messenger of Allah, shall you go out to them or shall they enter to you? The Prophet ﷺ said: I will go out to them. So he went out and said: O assembly of Quraysh, is there anyone among you other than yourselves? They replied: No, except the children of our sisters. The Prophet ﷺ said: The child of the sister of the people is from them. Then he said: O assembly of Quraysh, know that the closest of people to me are the God-fearing. Take care that people do not come to you on the Day of Resurrection with deeds while you come carrying this world that you are bearing. So I will turn my face away from you. Then he recited: Indeed, the closest of the people to Abraham are those who followed him and this Prophet and those who have believed. And Allah is the Guardian of the believers (Al-Imran 68).

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Qutaylah: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ stood among the people in the Farewell Pilgrimage and said: There is no prophet after me and there is no ummah after you. So worship your Lord, Mighty and Exalted, and establish prayer, give Zakat, fast your month, and obey those in authority among you, and you shall enter the Garden of your Lord.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated: Yahya ibn Abi Kathir was asked about finding a louse on one's clothes while praying. He replied: If one of you finds a louse on his clothes while praying, let him remove it from his garment until he takes it out of the mosque.
